etymologies: Middle English: the noun from Old French us, from Latin usus, from uti ‘to use’; the verb from Old French user, based on Latin uti

notes.text: The construction used to is standard, but difficulties arise with the formation of negatives and questions. Traditionally, used to behaves as a modal verb, so that questions and negatives are formed without the auxiliary verb do, as in it used not to be like that and used she to come here? In modern English this question form is now regarded as very formal or awkwardly old-fashioned and the use with do is broadly accepted as standard, as in did she use to come here? Negative constructions with do, on the other hand (as in it didn't use to be like that), though common, are informal and are not generally accepted. There is sometimes confusion over whether to use the form used to or use to, which has arisen largely because the pronunciation is the same in both cases. Except in negatives and questions, the correct form is used to: we used to go to the park all the time, not we use to go to the park all the time. However, in negatives and questions using the auxiliary verb do, the correct form is use to, because the form of the verb required is the infinitive: I didn't use to like mushrooms, not I didn't used to like mushrooms. See also utilize

definitions: take, hold, or deploy (something) as a means of accomplishing a purpose or achieving a result; employ

examples.text: she used her key to open the front door
the poem uses simple language

shortDefinitions: take, hold, or deploy something as means of accomplishing or achieving something

examples.text: use your troops well and they will not let you down

definitions: exploit (a person or situation) for one's own advantage

examples.text: I couldn't help feeling that she was using me

shortDefinitions: exploit person or situation for one's own advantage

definitions: apply (a name or title) to oneself

examples.text: she still used her maiden name professionally

shortDefinitions: apply name or title to oneself

examples.text: they were using heroin daily
had she been using again?

definitions: take or consume (an amount) from a limited supply

examples.text: we have used all the available funds

shortDefinitions: take or consume amount from limited supply

definitions: describing an action or state of affairs that was done repeatedly or existed for a period in the past

examples.text: this road used to be a dirt track
I used to give him lifts home

shortDefinitions: describing action or situation that was done repeatedly or existed for period in past

definitions: be or become familiar with someone or something through experience

examples.text: she was used to getting what she wanted
he's weird, but you just have to get used to him

shortDefinitions: be or become familiar with person or thing through experience

definitions: one would like or benefit from

examples.text: I could use another cup of coffee

shortDefinitions: one would like or benefit from

notes.text: The construction used to is standard, but difficulties arise with the formation of negatives and questions. Traditionally, used to behaves as a modal verb, so that questions and negatives are formed without the auxiliary verb do, as in it used not to be like that and used she to come here? In modern English this question form is now regarded as very formal or awkwardly old-fashioned and the use with do is broadly accepted as standard, as in did she use to come here? Negative constructions with do, on the other hand (as in it didn't use to be like that), though common, are informal and are not generally accepted. There is sometimes confusion over whether to use the form used to or use to, which has arisen largely because the pronunciation is the same in both cases. Except in negatives and questions, the correct form is used to: we used to go to the park all the time, not we use to go to the park all the time. However, in negatives and questions using the auxiliary verb do, the correct form is use to, because the form of the verb required is the infinitive: I didn't use to like mushrooms, not I didn't used to like mushrooms. See also utilize

definitions: the action of using something or the state of being used for a purpose

examples.text: modern trains are now in use
a few years after penicillin came into use
the water mill went out of use in 1960
theater owners were charging too much for the use of their venues
the software is ideal for use in schools

definitions: the ability or power to exercise or manipulate one's mind or body

examples.text: the horse lost the use of his hind legs

shortDefinitions: ability or power to exercise or manipulate one's mind or body

definitions: a purpose for or way in which something can be used

examples.text: the herb has various culinary uses

shortDefinitions: purpose for or way in which something can be used

definitions: the value or advantage of something

examples.text: what's the use of crying?

definitions: the benefit or profit of lands, especially lands that are in the possession of another who holds them solely for the beneficiary.
the habitual consumption of a drug

examples.text: theft and dealing financed their heroin use

definitions: the characteristic ritual and liturgy of a Christian Church or diocese.
shortDefinitions: characteristic ritual and liturgy of Christian Church or diocese
